q: What are the main causes of liver disease?
a: The main causes of liver disease are obesity, undiagnosed hepatitis infection, and alcohol misuse.

q: What are the symptoms of liver disease?
a: Symptoms of liver disease include feeling tired, loss of appetite, loss of sex drive, jaundice, itchy skin, and nausea.

q: What are the different types of liver disease?
a: Common types of liver disease include alcohol-related liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, hepatitis, haemochromatosis, and primary biliary cholangitis.

q: How can liver disease be prevented?
a: Liver disease can be prevented by maintaining a healthy weight, avoiding excessive alcohol consumption, and getting vaccinated for hepatitis A and B if at risk.

q: What lifestyle changes can help with liver disease?
a: For some types of liver disease, such as alcohol-related liver disease, quitting alcohol can help improve the condition. Maintaining a healthy weight is also beneficial.

q: When should I see a GP if I think I have liver disease?
a: If you suspect you have liver disease, it is advisable to see a GP for an evaluation and appropriate guidance.

q: What are the treatment options for liver disease?
a: The treatment for liver disease depends on the type and severity of the condition. It can range from lifestyle changes to medication or even liver transplant for severe cases.

q: Are there any organizations that offer support for liver disease?
a: The British Liver Trust and Children's Liver Disease Foundation are organizations that can provide advice and support for individuals diagnosed with liver disease.

q: Is hepatitis A vaccine available?
a: Yes, hepatitis A vaccine is available. It is recommended for those at risk of contracting the virus.

q: Is it necessary to drink excessive amounts of alcohol to risk liver damage?
a: No, regularly drinking just over the recommended levels of alcohol can also be harmful to your liver health.
